subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing
msgSnippet: ... Great point, and one that is often neglected by code coverage enthusiasts. -- Cédric [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
messageBody:
On 11/16/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
> On 16/11/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > Nobody disputes that 100% code coverage is a good thing, it's just that
> it
> > becomes impossibly hard to achieve as your code base becomes more
> complex.
> > You just need to make sure you don't hit the point of diminishing return
> > when trying to hit a balance between "more code coverage", "more tests",
> > "bug fixes" and "more features".
>
> The other part, of course, is that 100% code coverage still doesn't
> mean you've tested everything... there will still be logic paths
> through the code that are not exercised, and in any large enough
> program (say, above 10000 lines), these paths rapidly approach
> infiinty.


Great point, and one that is often neglected by code coverage enthusiasts.

--
Cédric


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
